My immediate assumption about the reason this has evolved to trigger on mechanical disturbance is so that it triggers when an animal is above, so that the animal carries the seeds with it in its fur / on its body.

You sort of touched on it, but I don't think "angular acceleration" is the only (or even primary) factor in ejecting the seeds. The seeds themselves do not bend, while the husk does. Thus, as the husk bends further, the surface area in contact with each seed decreases.

As the contact patch shrinks, the adhesion does as well.

Thank you for doing this experiment.  I moved to a new place last year and, this spring while trying to get the weeds out of the grass, ran into this plant.  I didn't want to spread the seeds from all of the weeds in the grass so, very logically, cut the stems on which the seed pods were developing and moved them to a bucket.  It worked for dandelions and other seed producers but this plant had me baffled.  I finally brought out a powerful vacuum and vacuumed the seeds as they popped out.  I'm still not convinced that I got a good percentage of them.  Just touching the stalk triggers the whipping of the seeds - often in my face.

So you know it’s Hairy bittercress (Cardamine hirsuta). In the study of seed dispersal there’s two types: autochory, seed is dispersed by the plant, and allochory, where the seed is dispersed by external means.

Hairy bittercress (which is not a grass) leafs out in a basal rosette, and like other members of the mustard family (Brassicaceae), its tender greens are edible. Don't be fooled by the common name—its flavor is mild and peppery, not bitter.

I have seen this in many forms with Australian native plants (I am a professional seed collector), and I see banana peal slap bracelet (it seems to be less common, but some of the banana peals can go either way depending on which end 'fails' first), I also see slap corkscrew quite commonly and sphere implosion on a few.  I think that there is a structure within the seed pod that creates tension in the pod walls as it dries, and eventually the tension gets to the point where the pod 'seam' fails and the tension is violently released throwing the seeds clear of the parent plant.

A few things worth mentioning, I think. If you really want to get smarter every day it's probably a good idea to know what you are talking about and/or listening to someone else talk about. The plant under consideration in this video has been identified as Arabidopsis thaliana which, if correct, makes it a member of the mustard (Brassicaceae) family.  This means that it is emphatically NOT a grass (family Poaceae), despite the fact that it is referred to as such numerous times in the video.  The shape and the arrangement of seeds in the fruits (capsules/pods) is highly suggestive of the pea/bean (Fabaceae) family.  Its explosive seed dispersal is neither rare nor limited to its genus or even family. I have, in my garden, two sister species (in the genus Impatiens (family Balsaminaceae)  that disperse their seeds in the same way.  They are both known by their common name; Touch Me Not.  Hm......does any of this matter?  Well, do you want to be smarter every day, or just smugger. Take a look at a few plants. Are they peas or trees.......or maybe both?

While I'm glad to see slow-mo video of these seed pods in action, I feel that up close and hands on observation of the seed pods could be just as effective for learning the steps that are taken in the release of seeds, from identifying the plant that releases seeds, observing said plant more closely to see where it comes from, and using the end results of a curled plant bit and scattered seeds to inform further experimentation. I learned the process last year, and I noted how quick it was from holding my fingers to both sides of the seed pod. By sliding them up or down, I could tell where it would begin curling from, and since there was no delay from sliding my fingers up to that released portion of the seed pod curling up, I could understand it was an incredibly fast process. A high speed camera certainly helps to visually show the unaltered process, but for understanding it on an individual level, I think it's overkill.

Bro thanks for this awesome video, I really very much appreciate all of your videos. Taking your google advice to the heart, I went on to check out what other sources say about this plant.
Turns out there is one little error in your video I believe, the exploding seed plant is a cardamine hirsuta, or hairy bittercress, in English. The plant you mention, Arabidopsis Thaliana (thale cress), is part of the research you show in your video that's called Morphomechanical Innovation Drives Explosive Seed Dispersal. Arabidopsis is a plant relative of cardamine which does not have exploding seeds and which they used as a reference in the research. Arabidopsis thaliana was the first plant ever to have its genome fully sequenced (I understand from wikipedia) and is therefore very well understood on a genetical and molecular level. That research seems extremely interesting, there's a video on sciencedirect (which I try to but don't really fully understand cuz i'm a noob enjoying videos like this one).

There is one more smart thing about this design. The fact that the process needs triggering. You know, if you are a plant, you don't want to just throw your seeds around and hope for the best, you want to tinker with the odds a bit. And this triggering requirement is exactly that.

In the wild there are no curious humans to mess up so the triggering happens when either a big enough insect hits the stalks or when a raindrop hits it. Big enough insects tend to lie buried in suspended animation until rain season arrives. Rain drops tend to occur when ... well, the rain season is named like that for a reason.

This helps the seeds to get their timing right. They are going to likely land into wet soil, allowing the seed to "disappear" from the view of seed eating insects, allowing it to sprout and produce offspring. If the seeds got released while still in the middle of the dry season, the probability of them being found and consumed by seed eating organisms is much higher as the seed will lie on too of the dry soil for a significant amount of time.

And I also have the reason to believe that the "wrap" not only serves as the launch mechanism but it also protects the seeds from the heat of the sun when the time is not yet ready for seed deployment.

Having read zero literature on this plant, based on the footage alone, I'd guess that the seed pod sides are subject to steadily increasing tension as the seeds are formed in the pod. When the seeds reach a certain size, the pod is under maximum tension and barely held together by the sides of the pod. When you disturb them, the bottom of the pod breaks off and the stored tension is released, causing the pod sides to curl. I'd suspect that if the pods weren't disturbed, the tension would eventually be great enough to cause the pods to explode on their own.

When the sheath curls up, I reckon the reduced surface contact to the seed is way more significant in releasing the seed vs the increase in angular momentum. Most of the angular velocity is reached in the initial transition from uncurled to curled. If it curls a little tighter, sure, that'd make it spin faster, but it also means that the amount of seed adhered to it is less (because the sheath is curling away from the seed). That's what causes the seed to let go, not the increase in spin speed. This hypothesis would take a lot of work to prove though.

@Destin - Think Critically: Very good. Now apply that to learning vocabulary. One does not "hone in" on a goal or answer, as said at 1:44 and again later. The correct phrase is "home in", like a homing pigeon, a homing beacon, a homing missile, etc. Hone refers to sharpening a thing, like a knife, or your mind. So please hone your vocabulary and never say "hone in" again, because it makes me cringe. Other frequently heard mistakes, probably not on this channel, confuse "cavalry" and "calvary" or "the notion" and "the fact".

It has been years ago that I first became fascinated with a similar phenomena demonstrated by a plant common here (NW USA): Scotch Broom is the local moniker. It has black pods that pop open in the late summer sun. If you sit near the plant on a particularly warm day, the pods split spontaneously and shower anything nearby with seeds. My presumption is that ripe pods dry in the sun. Dehydration causes the cells in the pods to shrink to the point where they overcome the bond holding the pod halves together, releasing the spring energy with an audible snap. I suspect the grass uses a similar mechanism.

Hey Dustin or whomever reads this! I have a question and I'm not sure how to even ask it in a way to get an answer. It involves water, and a phenomenon I've seen and can't explain. So, I live and work near a river. And every once in a while ill be down near on on the river working, and I'll notice what looks to be a line in the water. First time I saw it I thought it was a fishing line on top of the water, but when I ran my hand through it to grab it, nothing was there. But the line remained. I've seen many times and there is no discernable pattern to what causes the line. I've seen it in a river and the line goes to a convert, I've seen it go to a random point on the shore, I've seen it in a still lake just randomly going from shore to shore. And I do not know hat causes it. My first theory was that it was to different flows of water meeting, but that wouldn't happen in the middle of a river or in a still lake. My second theory is differing surface tension (like there is more oil or soap or something on one side than the other), but why would a still lake or a flowing river have differing water tensions? Its been bugging me for years and I have no answers

They had pre-tensioned spring layers that wanted to coil up like a slap bracelet, but were stretched out past straight in the football shape. They'd fling a couple seeds out, leaving a spirally tangle of the springs.

(they juices of the plant are also natural bug repellant)

Hey Destin, super cool video! I think you made a slight mistake while calculating the speed of the seeds. The camera is only capturing images from a single plane, and since the seeds are all flying in different directions (relative to the stationary camera) any calculation made using that footage will invariably have a differing degree of distortion for every seed due to the fact that the angle that the seed's trajectory makes with the plane that the camera is capturing is different for every seed.

Amazing video for something so seemingly random!  I read the paper you referenced, and one part got me thinking.  In it, they state: "These results show that drying is not the cause of exocarp cell shortening in C. hirsuta and suggest that exocarp shortening is an active process, requiring living cells that can sustain turgor pressure."   I then wondered; would a completely dried out stalk not release its seeds?  Or at least, not fling them out as far?  If so, could this suggest the plant as evolved so it releases seeds when conditions are right for seed growth i.e. after it rains or other environmental conditions are better (humidity, the season, etc) but then actively not release when conditions are not good for the seeds, like say if it's too dry out, or the plant has died (or is in hibernation due to heat, the season, etc).  What a crazy, complex world we live in.

The same thing happens to Acacia bush seed pods in the fall, only they often "trigger" without being touched, as I have seen this happen out at my Acreage, they usually "trigger" when they have fully dried out, but sometimes they freeze before they have the chance to pop, so things in early spring can get quite amusing when you go for a walk and happen to brush past an acacia bush, when you get back home you'll have acacia seeds in your hair, and sometimes inside your clothes making you itch mercilessly! my kids used to get a kick out of playing with them, after I made them aware of it. I always tried to include my children in outdoor activities and point out things like that to them and then ask them how THEY thought it happened. Oh one thing about the Acacias though is that it's not a Strap bracelet kid of thing by itself, but they spiral away from the other side of the pod is a corkscrew fashion with the seeds more or less unattached from the pod halves, not entirely unattached in many cases but hey, not everything goes according to plan, even in nature. But in the mid to late fall go out walking around acacias and you'll hear them popping by themselves or when they get touched and you'll see them doing it and because the pods are much larger than grass seed pods so you'll have a better time filming them, if you choose to do so. I wager that this is how MANY plants cause their seeds to be dispersed, how about Pine trees? they only fire off their seeds when exposed to fire, well, some trees do that, not sure if it's pine, it might be spruce or some other conifer that does it, but you can see the great Variety that Our Father in Heaven has created  for plants, that are stationary entities spread their seeds far enough away from the parent plant as to not cause the death of all their offspring. Isn't the natural world amazing?!?!?!

If in mid summrr you visit any woods with a creek flowing through, you will find yellow or spotted touch-me-not ((jewel weed). It has three-quarter to one inch, green banana shaped seed pods which open explosively when touched, ejecting the seeds. In any stand of these plants, there will be, simultaneously, various stages of maturity. Thus there will be the very pretty flowers (see Wikipedia entry) and ready-to-explode pods on the same plant. Should make for interesting filming.

From Wikipedia: "The seed pods have five valves which coil back rapidly to eject the seeds in a process called explosive dehiscence or ballistochory. This reaction is where the name 'touch-me-not' comes from; in mature seed pods, dehiscence can easily be triggered with a light touch."

Okay, I'm going to write out some hypotheses before watching the slow-mo.
In order for this to work there obviously needs to be a store of potential energy so a few ideas come mind:
A: A chemical reaction similar to a bombardier beatle's butt canon. It's possible for a living thing to do something like this, but I've never heard of a plant that can do it, so I think it's unlikely.
B: Water pressure. A plant's cell walls allow it to build up significant internal pressures. If I'm not mistaken, this is how a venus fly-trap works. This is the closest thing I know other plants can do, so of my wild guesses, this is the one I'd consider most likely.
C: Spring action. One of my house plants, when it grows a new flower, the flower starts curled up on itself. The bud holds the single petaled flower back until it's stem grows long enough for the tip of the petal to fully exit the bud. I can imagine with a stiffer bud/stem you could build up spring force. This is pure speculation on my part though, so I'd say this is the least likely of my hypotheses.

I’m commenting before watching (honest!) I loved these weeds as a kid. I spent a while playing with them, trying to figure out how they worked. From what I can tell (and remember) the seed pods grow asymmetrically, with a pair of ridges either side of the center that add rigidity and prevent it from buckling. As the pod matures and dries, the shorter side thins out until an animal, or even a stiff breeze breaks the membrane, causing the pod to coil up like a spring, flinging the seeds. Edit: Looks like I was more or less correct, although I admit, the slap bracelet is a far better description than what I gave, but I was more focusing on how the plant developed. Also, I had no idea it was double sided! That’s awesome!

I always enjoy your videos but it is really unfortunate the way that Google sponsored this content. Generally what you say in the advertisement is true but Google has been proven to be an unreliable tool for a lot of information. Rather than just aggregating results based on search terms, Google analyzes the results and applies a bias filter to give you only the results it wants you to see. This creates significant consequences because that filter is purely political. This causes obvious problems when researching political candidates but other side effects also show up as a result. Science is often hardest hit from this as the politics of science typically end up more important to Google than the actual science. This prevents competing ideas and discussion from taking place limiting dialogue that would normally propel science forward. Of course without any filter there will be unscientific results as well but it is far more important to include everything than to create limits that exclude legitimate alternatives.

Yes! Finally, a topic I have some first-hand background experience with! I’ve worked for four years in a lab that works with Arabidopsis. The whole seed pod together is called the silique, and the slap bracelets are called carpals. This video is so interesting to me because the ecotypes we work with in the lab don’t quite do the slap bracelet launch—we typically describe it as “shattering” or “bursting” and the carpels just fly straight off of the silique. One thing I noticed in your video is that you were interacting with mostly green looking siliques. I’m not sure if you observed this at all in your trials with the camera, but in our lab it’s typically easier to physically disturb than the yellow/brown looking siliques to “explode” than the green ones. This is because as the seeds mature inside the seed pod, the whole seed pod is programmed to dry out, as this makes the carpels fly off more easily and spreads the seeds better. Very interesting to see exactly how these weeds shoot their seeds. BUT - don’t mess with them at all if you want to get rid of them. I first noticed these guys showing up in a lawn 20-ish years ago. Had never encountered them before that. Now, years later I’ve seen them showing up everywhere. They started showing up in the lawn at my current home about 3-4yrs ago. Normal weed & feed fertilizers are not effective on them. I assume it would take a very strong herbicide that kills everything will get rid of this particular weed. Which kids and pets we don’t use any weed killers , so I’ve resorted to hunting for them in my lawn in the Spring, preferably before the seed pods mature, then pinch them at the stem below the branching and pull them out of the lawn. They have very shallow root systems and so come out easily. It has taken three seasons to rid them from a few areas they were spreading in.

Now I'm trying to understand how these pods build up the potential energy required to curl the outside of the pods. I think the outside of the pods gets dried out a bit in the sun, which causes it to shrink slightly. This would result in tension on the outer surface, while the inner surface is still moist and resists this tension. When the outside of the pod has become sufficiently dry, it just takes a small disturbance to break the base (which is narrower than the pod, making it a break-away point), releasing all that tension like a bimetallic strip.

I'd like to add something to your caution.  The internet / search engine is a giant "YES" Machine.  Ninety nine times out of a hundred, what ever you ask it, it will respond with "Yes, and here is some more!" So it is imperative that you understand this before asking questions like "Were the moon landings faked?"  If you do, you will only hear from people who think they were.  And it can appear like everyone believes that but its really your search engine that was at fault for creating that illusion.  I stumbled across this while trying to discover what was making my dog sick. So I asked "Did Purina (for ex.) make my dog sick?"  Right away I was presented with half a dozen stories of ill dogs that their owners thought was due to my dog food. I really thought I was on to something, and then I tried this:  "Did Alpo make my dog sick?" 20+ hits all from people who believed Alpo had made their dog sick. I tried the same with two other brands.  What I slowly realized is that for any sentence you might create, chances are very good that someone has posted something similar somewhere. So that is the point, be careful what you ask because whatever it is, its likely your browser will respond with YES!

A couple things... First, this is not a grass. Grasses comprise everything from bamboo to sugarcane, rice, barley, rye, and oats to bermuda grass to kentucky bluegrass. No grasses employ ballistic seed dispersal from capsules like this. Second, Mouse-ear Cress is a broadleaved annual/biennial species in the Mustard Family. The Mustard Family also includes mustard, cabbage, horse radish, wasabi, kohlrabi and broccoli, plus a lot of variously named cresses. It's possible this is Hairy Bittercress if the leaves are deeply lobed, almost like fern leaves. It's much more common in your area than Mouse-ear Cress. Thanks for such an amazing video! I'm glad you did this one. One morning, about 5 years ago, while getting in my car to head off to work, I saw a strange 'fog' moving across my yard. It was this effect. I had about a 500 sq foot area of my yard that had not been mowed down yet. The grass was about a foot in height, and the tassels (?) were almost half of that height. The fog I was seeing was actually the seeds popping out. As far as I could tell, there was no mechanical trigger, unless it was triggered by other seeds hitting other pods.
It seemed to start out very slow, from one end of the yard, and rapidly grew into a crescendo of what looked like the entire yard giving up seeds at once, and ended slowly at the other end of the yard. The entire thing lasted about 5 seconds. When it was over there were still occasionally random pops in random places for a few more seconds. Then it was all over. I have never seen it happen since then, and I always watch for it. Beautiful!

You've got to be really silly if you watched this and still believe evolution created everything. This seed distribution system is a perfect example of irreducible complexity. In random evolution by mutation theory, how many iterations had to  evolve before this seed distribution system was achieved? The problem is that those intermediate iteration mutations served no function on their own. And yet, you only have 2 possibilities: it springs back and spreads the seeds, or not - meaning that the plant can't procreate and it will die out after that one mutation iteration, or one generation. The seed spreading device had to work the very first iteration, which is impossible by random chance, only by design.

Thanks for this cool video! I learned a lot!!! I thought you might like to know a little more about this plant. As you noted, the common name is "Hairy Bittercress," and the Latin/scientific name is Cardamime hirsuta. It was named by Linnaeus, the 18th C. Swedish botanist and taxonomist. Hairy Bittercress is not native to the USA, but came from Europe--maybe brought on purpose, because it is possibly edible, like watercress. (But please don't eat it until you check with someone who's more learned about it than I am!!!) We call it a weed because it grows where we don't want it--like in lawns and gardens. But, "weed" is a value judgment, not a technical term. Hey, some people grow dandelions in their gardens on purpose for food and medicine!!!

Hairy Bittercress is not a grass, but a member of the the mustard family, to which (among lots of other plants) broccoli belongs! I like Hairy Bittercress, because it is usually the first plant I see growing and then blooming in the spring--it has four tiny white petals. Eventually, each flower makes one of those pods--the pod starts growing up from the middle of the petals, and the petals fall off. By the way, you can see one of its "divided" leaves at 1:58, just below a little purple flower.

Hairy Bittercress is an annual plant--it lasts only one year. That's why it has to send out as many seeds as it can. I knew it shot out its seeds, but now I know how! Another fun nature story!!!!

If you like the way these seeds are distributed, check out how BlueBonnets (Texas wildflower) disperse their seeds.  One side of the seedpod shell has an inherent twist to one side, while the other side of the shell has a twist to the opposite direction.  When the seeds get mature and the pod shell gets to the right level of dryness, the tension between the two opposite twisting shells reaches a critical point and they snap, sending the BlueBonnet seeds flying!

This has to be a factor so young pods can grow and not trigger the seeds early and launch immature seeds, and on the other end of the scale, eventually the pod will get too dry and snap on it's own launching seeds before they die on the plant.

Himalayan Balsam seed pods does something very similar at a much larger scale. Unfortunately it's such an effective seed distribution method that the invasive plant has caused significant environmental impact, especially to river banks here in Ireland. Their tall structure outcompetes native plants and produces much more nectar making the plant more attractive to bees, which supports the spread of the species and less pollination of our native plants. They also have a very shallow root base, so when the plants die back in October, they leave the soil more exposed to weathering and erosion.

A skim of the research paper told me it's not actually drying, rather increased hydrostatic pressure within cells leading to expansion in one dimension and contraction in the other, that builds up the explosive stress in the seed heads. Either way, the idea is that through some fabrics and materials with varying permeability and designed geometry, you might concoct a multilayered version of this slap bracelet banana peel, where the weight and expansion due to soaking in rainfall drive the slap bracelets from their curled state, to their straightened state. Then, as drying slowly occurs in days after the rainfall, one-by-one, the outermost layer dries or diffuses the water its holding in such a way that builds up stress and ultimately explosively releases that layer to its curled state; where in the explosion the layer is wiped across the solar panel and perhaps releases water from some storage vessels within it, flinging water droplets like seeds. In this way, the solar panel gets cleaned every day or two for a couple weeks after each significant rainfall.

in the spirit of not short-cutting to the answer, here is my guessing process: 1st, I kinda assumed the plant fibers acted like springs or rubber bands. @ 2:08 the seeds in slow-mo look curled. If the plant fibers were acting as a sort of rubber band, I think the seeds would be straighter (if not rigid at least) so my 2nd guess is that the seeds also act as the stretchy exterior wall to a chamber that is pressurized. so then, when the pressure chamber plant-walls dry, the seams become weak, so any physical disturbance cracks the seam, releasing the pressure which BLASTS the seed off, which is no longer under tension so it is allowed to curl. I've only made it to 2:14 so far, so guess i'll find out how close i am.

What is truth? While the desire to combat misinformation certainly sounds noble, if you can't answer the question of what is truth then there is no way to discern between misinformation and correct information. And the reality stands that there isn't a way to answer the question without a statement of faith: be it trust (aka faith) in our perceptions (individual or group aka consensus), trust in authorities (ex fact checkers), a trust in a lack of malicious intent from others...

Everyone is a philosopher, just most aren't very rigorous. The scientific method cannot speak into many areas of reality: what is truth, ethics, knowledge, meaning... That does not make these things false, in fact I regard them as the most important things in life.

大家都知道荆轲刺秦王的故事，我们读了《孟子》这一段关于养勇的道理，再读《史记•刺客列传》时，对于荆轲的传记，不必读完全篇，就可以根据孟子所说养勇的两个典型原理断定荆轲剌秦王一定不会成功。这也是司马迁写《史记》的文学技巧高明之处，他牢牢地把握了荆轲这个人的人格特性，可以说把荆轲的灵魂和骨髓都写出来了。

荆轲这个人，好读书，爱击剑，文武全才，他的剑术造诣很高。他曾经到赵国榆次去拜访赵国的剑术名家盖聂，要和盖聂比剑。他大喝一声，拔出剑来，可是盖聂站在原地，纹风不动，“怒而目之”，以非常威严的眼神看住荆轲。这种眼神，就是一种“不肤挠，不目逃”的神气，荆轲被他眼神所慑，便收剑入鞘，回头就走。有人问这是怎么回事，盖聂说，他的神没有养到家，被我的眼神慑服了。然后荆轲又到邯郸去会有名的豪客鲁句践，两个人一起赌博，因此争路道，鲁句践光火，大声凶狠地讦责他，荆轲又一声不响地走了。鲁句践的气势，同样的，把荆轲逼走了。由此可见荆轲的养气炼神的工夫都不够上乘水平，所以他刺秦始皇会失败，更何况秦始皇的武功也很高。谈到练武，勇气固然重要，但修心养性的涵养工夫，可以说比武功更为重要。

我们再冋来看孟子对孟施舍的介绍。这位孟大侠的勇有四个要点，我们必须注意。第一，自己对自己要有信心，如果自己失去信心，那就不用说了。第二，要准确地衡量对方的能力。第三，抓住对方的弱点。第四，也是最重要的一点，行动时要小心谨慎，绝不轻视对方。具备这四个条件，才算得上“勇”。不论个人的武功成就也好，两军对垒作战也好，乃至平常面临艰危困难，如何去克服，如何善处艰危，都需要有这样的勇气。虽然未必一定有百战百胜的把握，但失败的机会总不会太多了。——《孟子与公孙丑》

I looked at the pods and they pop open because the fiber material of the pods grows in a curve that puts it in tension, and the pods release tension by splitting open. I'm very sorry Destin, I love your video's, but I'm cringing at this one. These are NOT grass seeds. They're the seeds of the Cardamine hirsuta, commonly called hairy bittercress. They're better catagorized as flowers. These are from the same family as cabbages, rucola, mustard, radishes, rapeseeds, ... Please do a little bit more research next time you do a video on plants. Another invasive species that does this trick is the Impatiens glandulifera. Altough they're from a totaly different plant family they use a similar seed throwing mechanism. Maybe it's usefull to make a follow up video and compare them. I'm very sorry for the critique (except for this one) you're doing an excellent job. Thanks for al the interesting video's.

Where I grew up there was a vaguely similar plant: a small shrub-like thing, that grew small (4-7 cm long) cucumber-like fruits on it. The free end of these "cucumbers" had a brownish short "beard" that was sensitive to touch. When the "cucumber" was ripe, any touch to this beard, however slight, would cause the "cucumber" to explode! Obviously not explode in a dangerous way, but more than enough to spread the seeds over a large area. You could absolutely hold the "cucumber" in your hand and set of the explosion, the only result would have been a need to wash your hand from the remainders of the "cucumber". Unfortunately, I never got to know what the name of this shrub was, but I would love to find out.

There's a genus of weeds called Ruellia and their distribution is throughout the Americas. As I only work with a specific species (complex, R. nudiflora ), that has a distribution from the southern US to southern Mexico (from Texas to the Yucatan peninsula), commonly known as Petunias. But the way the genus disperses its seeds seems to be similar to this Arabidopsis thanliana (which by the way, it's a model species and it is also non-mycorrhizal... which is an interesting trait since most plants form mycorrhiza). Ruellia has a fruit that, as it dries, tries to open up, but the top part of the fruit stops it from opening. The more it dries the more the stronger the force as it tries to pull itself apart. Time or a bit of water on the top seems to trigger the fruit open. The top of the fruit loses strength and the fruit simply explodes, with a snapping sound, sending seeds very far away. The system doesn't seem to be as intricate as A. thaliana, but I would personally love to see it happening in slow-mo since I work with that plant. I may try to sending you a video of it if I can, but I'm not sure where to share it.
Edit: the species in the video is actually Cardamine hirsuta

I "discovered" these exploding seeds in my garden a while back, and this year I was taking macro pictures of some small white flowers, only to notice a strange brown stalk emerging from the centre of some of the flowers.
Turns out the seed pod grows upwards leaving the petals behind, often for a long time, creating these weird flowers-with-antenna.
As they matured and grew little bumps I realized they were indeed the "catapult seeds" as I called them, so I set out to trying and get a slow motion macro shot of them.
I waited and waited, prodding the little patch once in a while to check if they were ready to fire, until I forgot and eventually remembered too late. Grass had been cut, too, so no more seeds :(

Hey, Plant Geneticist here!
I'm very sure, this is not Arabidopsis thaliana. Actually, it looks more like a Cardamine sp. (they are very closely related though).
Interestingly, most of Genetic Research in Plants is conducted in Arabidopsis and very few people look at her close relative Cardamine, although they show very interesting features, like this explosive seed dispersal.
Anyway, just wanted to let you know, great video regardless! :)

Hey Destin, love the video, but I disagree with you about how the plant springs. You describe it as a “reverse banana slap bracelet”, but I think what happens isa bit different. After the plant covers the seed with the outer layer of the seed pod, it dries it out. When this happens the outer layer contracts, and when the plant is disturbed it breaks at the bottom of the pod. I have multiple reasons for this assumption too, one is that it requires a rather strong material to make a slap bracelet like mechanism, and another is from my own observations of a plant we have in Idaho. It is a large bush full of peas, and late in the season it dries out the peas and they explode, because they have very small fibers connected the shell together. However, I have looked at no research papers, I have only reverse engineered it in my own head and talked to my mom, (who is a botanist). Thank you for the amazing and original content over the years.

I have the hairy bittercress in my yard and I try to get them out before they go to seed. Those seeds can really fly!

Very similarly, have a look at poppy seeds, e.g. California Golden Poppy - bit larger so, can pretty much catch it all with the naked eye - and though still small, large enough you can hear them pop - no equipment needed to be able to hear them pop.
For more bonus bits sit in front of 'em on a hot Summer day when they've gone to seed - if there's a bunch of 'em and you sit, listen, and watch carefully, you'll hear various among them popping and seeing the seeds and outer bit of seed pod go flying.
The poppies are slightly different though - the pods have a spiral component to them too - otherwise quite like the grass seeds.
And to see similar on even larger scale, look at some of the ornamental sweat peas - much bigger seeds and pods.
And all of the above, when they're ready to pop - the slightest disturbance, and they pop - or even just hot dry sun and bit of time - just sit, listen, and watch.

That is not Arabidopsis, although it is in the same family. That species is almost certainly hairy bittercress (Cardamine hirsuta), and that form of seed dispersal is called explosive dehiscence. It has been independently evolved by different taxa, including some members of the mustard family (like Cardamine and Arabidopsis) as well as things like impatiens and Oxalis.

It's also worth nothing that not everything that grows in a lawn is a type of grass. Grasses are specific kinds of plants that belong to the family poaceae, none of the ones I mentioned above are grasses.

This was fantastic! I loved following along in the process of discovery, vs just seeing the final result; our minds have a similar love for that process 😀

It was interesting to me how far off my initial thinking was; for some reason, all I could think of was some kind of compressed gas scenario, but it didn’t make sense to me that the plant would be able to build up a reservoir of compressed gas.

Once I saw the first slow-mo of the husks peeling up, it was like someone suddenly shone a bright light on the whole thing for me 😃🎉

Of course! Stored mechanical energy, and not only that, but it costs the plant almost nothing to create it! It just grows a normal sort of a seed husk, then lets the sun and air do all the work, building up stress as the husks dry, until some minor disturbance lets the whole thing rip! Huge energy produced and released, at almost zero cost to the plant. Brilliant!!

Thanks for sharing the whole process with us like this! (Now I just wish I had a Phantom camera for myself! 😕)

The reason you found many scientific publication on Arabidobsis Thatliana is that it's a so called model organism. Concepts in plant sciences often have to be displayed in this plant (even if it may make more sense to use another plant, people are familiar with this one and want to see things work in Arabidobsis). Other examples of model organisms are rats, C. elegans (nematode), and E. coli (bacteria).

- common blue Violet (Viola sororia)
- Jewelweed/spotted touch-me-not (Impatiens capensis).

@SmarterEveryDay Dustin, this is definitely Cardamine hirsuta, which is in the mustard family and not a grass, the mechanism of seed dispersal is similar to Arabidopsis thaliana which is also in the mustard family.  Nearly all mustard family plants have this type of seed dispersal.  If you want to see a slightly different mechanism of spring-loaded seed dispersal you should check out Impatiens capensis ('spotted jewelweed' or 'spotted touch-me-not').  They are native flowers found commonly in moist ditches or along creeks or floodplain forests.  They also have hydrophobic hairs on their leaves that trap air on their leaves that turn a reflective silver color underwater (hence the name jewelweed).

I don't think that angular momentum is the main force separating the seeds from the shell. Instead, I think it works a lot like separating ice cubes from a silicone ice tray. When the shell bends, the seeds get 'popped out' in the same way as ice cubes.

My reasoning is that the stickiness of plants is greatly influenced by moisture level (a dry plant isn't as sticky as a moist), and these seeds pop about the same way no matter if they are wet or dry. Angular momentum still plays a part, but I don't think it's the driving force
